review_title: Great place to work with great people

pros: Meritocracy, great compensation, very healthy work life balance, a lot of very smart and creative people who enjoy working in teams, awesome place to learn.

review_title: Challenging, engaging environment with great sense of work life balance

pros: Culture that encourages communication across disciplines Team-based approach that encourages employees to learn from one another Work life balance and keeping employees happy and empowered is at the core of the culture

years_at_company: I have been working at Chicago Trading Company full-time for less than a year

years_at_company: I have been working at Chicago Trading Company full-time
pros: 1. great colleagues and manager that are willing to teach and help. 2. great food. 3. good salary.
cons: nothing I can think of for now.

years_at_company: I have been working at Chicago Trading Company full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Pay is phenomenal and very team oriented environment. Great lunch benefit.
cons: Highly political not in the corporate sense but leftist. If you are right leaning politically (not just a Trump supporter which I’m not) don’t let people know. They frequently say highly disparaging things about conservatives at social outings and in the office. I’ve been on multiple teams and this is frequently the case. It’s really soured what was previously a good experience. I’ve overheard gleefully calling republicans racist and sexist which really has no place in the office.

years_at_company: I have been working at Chicago Trading Company full-time for more than 10 years
pros: Great benefits Great work life balance Job security Some very talented employees Good education/development of new hires Successful track record
cons: -The lack of opportunity for growth in the last few years has led to some extremely odd behavior... -Employee performance review and comp based on reputation with type A personalities favored and pretty much zero data behind compensation. -Non-white male employees are undervalued, under compensated and underrepresented in management. -Many managers holding their direct reports back in order protect their own job security. -Managers/upper mangers that have been responsible for countless talented employees leaving the firm are protected by their political connections. -Promotions almost entirely based on political maneuvering, specially a very strange obsession with holding inconsequential meetings non stop in hopes of gaining recognition/political points with managers. -Partnership being politically left leaning has flowed into managers openly displaying their left leaning beliefs in hopes of career advancement, with apolitical/right leaning employees feeling alienated. -Stealing of others ideas and work.

years_at_company: I have been working at Chicago Trading Company full-time for more than 5 years
pros: This is a great company where all desks try to collaborate together and with a great atmosphere
cons: Could use more resources for technology

years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company full-time
pros: Some nice people. Pay is good.
cons: Closed group at the top.

review_title: Superb Team, Superb Technology, Superb Experience
years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I was challenged and encouraged to expand my skillset every day that I worked at CTC. The company has great leadership, supportive middle management, and a broad spectrum of top notch trading and technical teams.

years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company full-time

years_at_company: I have been working at Chicago Trading Company full-time
pros: good pay and benefits free food nice people

years_at_company: I have been working at Chicago Trading Company full-time
pros: Workers create a great environment to work in. Always looking for new ways to improve so it's a very dynamic and fast-paced environment. Great perks like pay, free breakfast/lunch, company parties.
cons: There is a bit of a divide between the trading side of things and the software side of things. It would be nice if this could be bridged in some way.

years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company full-time
pros: Great work life balance. Nice pay and perks. Nice annual party. Collaborative environment. Nice people to work with. Good core values.
cons: It's still a small company at heart. Promotions are not always meritocratic, but often based on relationships with upper management. That's not to say it's all that way but if you aren't part of the inner circle you will have to work twice as hard for promotions. It's not nefarious, it's just human nature, but sadly that's the way it is. Also they appear to be content with their current company, so expansion opportunities are not likely to happen. That means if you are a newly hired be prepared for that role to be your last one. It won't necessarily be the case, but prepare yourself for that potential reality.

review_title: You will either Love it or Hate it

cons: Lack of business ethics cliques, promotions based on political maneuvering Lack of any ethics (But that can be a hindrance in prop trading)

years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company full-time for more than 3 years

review_title: Good company on a good trajectory

years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company full-time for more than a year

years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company full-time

years_at_company: I have been working at Chicago Trading Company full-time for more than 3 years

years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company

cons: Lots of legacy systems. Expect plenty of fire fighting. Limited compensation upside. Was told what developers can at when I joined. I've seen better work-life balance. Telecommuting strongly discouraged. Teams are a bit segregated and don't work together as well as they could.

years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company full-time

pros: Work with smart people CTC Education / training program Free lunch and breakfast Beautiful spacious office Competitive compensation Meritocratic culture Work hard with reasonable hours - great work/life balance Mostly supportive management

years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company part-time for less than a year

review_title: Don't take the job unless desperate.
years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Nice office. Awesome lunch program.
cons: Everything else. Specifically management. They fire/push out the door all of the talent and it shows. Promotions go to the most political butt kissers, while the best have their ideas stolen and then fired. Oh and remember the time they didn't even know about the gas trades that lost them a ton of money? There went the New York and London office. Not to mention rampant racism and sexism in management. Hands down the worst place I have ever worked.

review_title: Exciting development at a more honorable trading firm
years_at_company: I have been working at Chicago Trading Company full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Software developers can learn a lot about builing high-performance distributed systems. CTC has some outstanding technologists who have built great systems. Most of the people are sharp and nice. All CTC employees can learn about options pricing. They have a couple required classes and then a lot of optional classes run by a solid in-house education department. (One of the teachers used to be at the University of Chicago's financial math program.) Chicago Trading Company is also one of the more honorable trading firms-- they mostly stay out of shady areas of finance, and traders don't scream at developers. They also offer good work/life balance-- people go home by 5, some even by 4.
cons: - Software developers have to do a fair amount of support (including the occasional middle-of-the-night call), even though there is a front-line support team. - The company takes unusually long to get off of legacy technology, starting 2nd and 3rd generation applications without fully shutting down the 1st generation application. I think this is because upper management makes a mandate to get off the 1st gen stuff but has no plan about what needs to be done to achieve that. - As of spring 2014, software development is being reshuffled, from a system where development was controlled primarily by the desks to a more centralized development. It might be good to wait until the dust has settled.

review_title: Can be a good experience if you can survive
years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company full-time for less than a year
pros: Fency office furniture, free food, very good internal education programs; The annual 360 Performance Evaluation is a nightmare.
cons: no opprtunities for the carrier and salary growth unless you are well connected

review_title: Good company to learn options trading
years_at_company: I have been working at Chicago Trading Company
pros:
-- good training program
-- meritocratic advancement
cons: -- excitement in the job depends on market conditions.

years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company full-time for more than 3 years
pros: For most people, a really great place to work. High integrity, passionate and talented employees, generous benefits, energetic environment. Work/life balance is a core value. Some of the smartest traders and technologists I've ever worked with. Their business strategies are largely insulated from market conditions, and they are positioned to profit regardless of the state of the underlying or volatility markets.
cons: Upward mobility is absolutely capped. You can get paid, but the leadership structure is set in concrete and unless someone leaves/retires, you're staying right where you are. Path to partnership is unknown and unknowable. Traders have a little too much influence on the tactical decisions in technology, resulting in inefficiency and sometimes paralysis. Progress is hard. "Rock stars" are identified and given too much credit/adulation relative to their peers.

years_at_company: I have been working at Chicago Trading Company full-time for more than 3 years
pros: smart people, teamwork oriented. generous benefits, especially for more junior people.
cons: it used to be that you'd get stuck in one area for a long time but i think they changed that now.

review_title: Great place to work with smart developers.
years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company full-time for more than 3 years
pros: Free food, great co-workers, laid back
cons: Would not pay market rates

employee_status: Senior Software Engineer in Chicago, IL
years_at_company: I have been working at Chicago Trading Company
pros: I've been a software engineer for over 10 years in the Chicago area, and I've been at a big 5 consulting firm, and this is now my third prop trading shop. It's the best place I've been so far. - Great benefits, compensation - Work with incredibly smart people - Fully stocked kitchen, free breakfast and lunch(so much so that there is a phenomenon known as the CTC 15) - Passionate workforce. I can't say enough about this, I have yet to meet anyone at CTC that I thought didn't care and was just going through the motions. - Wonderful educational opportunities - The in house education department(3 full time people) is great.
cons: - Promotions across teams can seem unfair. The bar for promotion on team A may seem much higher than the bar for promotion on team B. This has been an issue at every firm I've ever worked at or been a part of, but still, it happens. - Other than that, my gripes are very persnickety(like why can't we get skim milk in the upstairs fridge?)

years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company
pros: Good education/training system; Opportunities to work together with traders; Knowledge sharing is clear and fast; Free breakfast and lunch; Company sponsored events.
cons: The company is suffering from growing pains -- the top level management needs to realize that with more and more administrative level people coming to the company, the productivity of employees and information passing between people are actually becoming not so clear and timely. Some are taking advantage of this. Some get promoted, but they don't deserve it.

years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company
pros: You will work with a lot of smart people in a casual work environment; free lunch; good pay and benefits; -first-year base salary was higher than most of my college classmates' (not including bonus) -Opportunity to learn options trading theory is outstanding--educators are top-notch and traders are generally very smart and knowledgeable -CTC is a respected firm in the options market-making space -excellent benefits-free breakfast (depending on your group), free lunch and fully stocked kitchen -fast paced environment -many after-work activities like happy hours, intra-mural sports, etc help to create bonds -CTC initiated a subsidy program for employees to take classes at local universities
cons: Mentorship wasn't great. You will need thick skin to work here. You will get screamed at for making mistakes.

employee_status: Trading Assistant in New York, NY
review_title: Work-hard-party-hard atmosphere, as expected at an options market-making and prop-trading shop
years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company
pros: -first-year base salary was higher than most of my college classmates' (not including bonus) -Opportunity to learn options trading theory is outstanding--educators are top-notch and traders are generally very smart and knowledgeable -CTC is a respected firm in the options market-making space -excellent benefits-free breakfast (depending on your group), free lunch and fully stocked kitchen -fast paced environment -many after-work activities like happy hours, intra-mural sports, etc help to create bonds -CTC initiated a subsidy program for employees to take classes at local universities
cons: -they do not have a strong mentorship program, though this was advertised when I first started -strong sense of a clique--if you are not liked, it becomes very obvious very quickly, and you will be intimidated constantly -very much a frat-like office -you will get screamed at if you make the same mistake twice--must have VERY thick skin to work here -personal growth outside of trading was not strongly encouraged

review_title: Best company I have ever worked for
years_at_company: I worked at Chicago Trading Company
pros: Profitable company with a long term vision Clear strategy that is well communicated Truly values integrity, particularly in the way it treats staff. Honest, trustworthy and transparent management and culture Long term greedy, not willing to sacrifice principles or values to make a short term profit. Very social and inclusive workplace.
cons: Career opportunities can be a bit limiting, but nothing surprising given the industry and company size.
